comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I bet it is the Botanic Gardens looking east from Macquarie Street towards Woolloomooloo and Darlinghurst,  near where the Garden Palace was.   Probably part of a panorama.  More research required - anyone else?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] How about a larger view to help? I've replaced this with a larger version - the buildings in the background might be of help in identifying the park.

AB

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: The rows of terrace houses in the middle distance suggest the Botanic Gardens - but the 'fall' of the land looks wrong to me - Woolloomooloo is in a valley -  do the authorities that run the gardens have any old pictures with which to compare?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Thanks for the larger view - it always helps.

That distinctive pyramid-shaped roof middle left is the Museum (see note) -  

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4272992142/]

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] It didn't take long for you to identify this park! Thank you very much, I have updated the caption to "Royal Botanic Gardens". 

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
My (not-very-scientific) calculations put the photographer on top of the Colonial / Chief Secretary's Office at the corner of Macquarie and Bridge Streets.

It must be fairly soon after the 1882 Garden Palace fire, as the newly planted trees have not grown too much.  Certainly not before the Garden Palace (built in 1879),  because of the telephone wires.  Circa 1885?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Part of a panorama view. Panning left -

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I see another stitching project in the works!

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I am wondering if this photo has something (or a lot) to do with John Rae who owned a house in Macquarie Street, from which he photographed a panorama.  This one seems to be from a lower level.  See comments -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8146286125/]
